content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata xml:lang="en"> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>The Wilderness Society</origin> <pubdate>2011</pubdate> <title>Potential Evapotranspiration Estimates (mm) for for Alaska, ECHAM5 - A1B scenario. The Wilderness Society,  2011.</title> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <onlink>http://www.snap.uaf.edu/downloads/alaska-climate-datasets</onlink> <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/products/spatial-data/show/potential-evapotranspiration-echam5-a1b-scenario</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract> Potential Evapotranspiration (PET):  These data represent decadal mean totals of potential evapotranspiration estimates (mm). The file name specifies the decade the raster represents. For example, a file named pet_mean_mm_decadal_MPI_ECHAM5_A1B_annual_2000-2009.tif represents the decade spanning 2000-2009.  The data were generated by using the Hamon equation and output from ECHAM5, a fifth generation general circulation model created by the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg Germany.  Data are at 2km x 2km resolution, and all data are stored in geotiffs. Calculations were performed using R 2.12.1 and 2.12.2 for Mac OS Leopard, and data were formatted into geotiffs using the raster and rgdal packages.  Users are reminded that the PET estimates include the inherent uncertainty of model projections. In addition, the methods used to derive PET from temperature require a number of assumptions, which future conditions may or may not meet. In particular, these methods as implemented assume that cloudcover and relative humidity remain constant. This may or may not be true.  Hamon Equation: These data were derived by applying the Hamon equation as outlined in Lu et al. (2005) to monthly average temperature downscaled by SNAP. </abstract> <purpose>The Wilderness Society derived potential evapotranspiration from temperature projections to better understand how potential future warming might influence the surface water budget.</purpose> <supplinf> ECHAM5 data provided by SNAP.  The data files downloaded from SNAP represent a single month within a given year from the ECHAM5 model under the A1B emission scenario.  The A1B scenario assumes a world of very rapid economic growth, a global population that peaks in mid-century, rapid introduction of new and more efficient technologies, and a balance between fossil fuels and other energy sources. The outputs from the ECHAM5 model have been scaled down to 2 kilometer resolution using the PRISM model (http://www.prism.oregonstate.edu/), which takes into account elevation, slope, and aspect.  Please note that these maps represent climate estimations only. While SNAP has based their work on the best data and methods available, uncertainty is inherent in modeling. </supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>2000</begdate> <enddate>2099</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>Unknown</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-180.000000</westbc> <eastbc>180.000000</eastbc> <northbc>74.855485</northbc> <southbc>46.118994</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt> <themekey>climatologyMeteorlogyAtmosphere</themekey> </theme> <place> <placekt>User</placekt> <placekey>Alaska</placekey> </place> </keywords> <accconst>None.</accconst> <useconst>It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate data set limitations, restrictions or intended use.  The Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning, The Wilderness Society, and the Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.</useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>The Wilderness Society</cntorg> <cntper>Wendy Loya</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype> <address>705 Christensen Dr.</address> <city>Anchorage</city> <state>Alaska</state> <postal>99501</postal> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>907-272-9453</cntvoice> <cntfax>907-272-1670</cntfax> <cntemail>wendy_loya@tws.org</cntemail> <cntinst> Contact_Instructions:  Please direct questions about SNAP or the downscaled temperature projections to:  University of Alaska c/o Nancy Fresco SNAP Network Coordinator P.O. Box 757200 Fairbanks, Alaska 99775-7200 USA 907-474-2405 (voice) 907-474-6184 (FAX) nlfresco@alaska.edu Hours_of_Service: 8:30am - 4:00pm </cntinst> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <datacred>The Wilderness Society and Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning</datacred> <secinfo> <secsys>FIPS Pub 199</secsys> <secclass>No Confidentiality</secclass> <sechandl>Standard Technical Controls</sechandl> </secinfo> <crossref> <citeinfo> <origin>Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning</origin> <pubdate>2008</pubdate> <title>Scenarios Network for Alaska and Arctic Planning, 2008 - ECHAM5 Air Temperature - A1B.</title> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <onlink>http://www.snap.uaf.edu/downloads/alaska-climate-datasets</onlink> </citeinfo> </crossref> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>The input temperature files have been checked to determine that the downscaled output is consistent between CRU and the GCM output. The PET scripts have been proof-read by two people. Results have been reviewed to determine that PET rates are in-line with expectations for the region, but no attempt was made to do a systematic or geographically explicit cross-check against published PET values.</logic> <complete>This dataset covers the state of Alaska.</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc> 1. Downloaded source data from http://www.snap.uaf.edu. 2. Calculations were performed using R 2.12.1 and 2.12.2 for Mac OS Leopard 3. Data were formatted into geotiffs using the raster and rgdal packages. </procdesc> <procdate>2011</procdate> <proccont> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>The Wilderness Society</cntorg> <cntper>Wendy Loya</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype> <address>705 Christensen Dr.</address> <city>Anchorage</city> <state>Alaska</state> <postal>99501</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>907-272-9453</cntvoice> <cntfax>907-272-1670</cntfax> <cntemail>wendy_loya@tws.org</cntemail> <cntinst>Contact by phone or email.</cntinst> </cntinfo> </proccont> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <direct>Raster</direct> <rastinfo> <rasttype>Grid Cell</rasttype> </rastinfo> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <planar> <mapproj> <mapprojn>Albers Conical Equal Area</mapprojn> <albers> <stdparll>55</stdparll> <stdparll>65</stdparll> <longcm>-154</longcm> <latprjo>50</latprjo> <feast>0</feast> <fnorth>0</fnorth> </albers> </mapproj> <planci> <plance>coordinate pair</plance> <coordrep> <absres>0.002048</absres> <ordres>0.002048</ordres> </coordrep> <plandu>meters</plandu> </planci> </planar> <geodetic> <horizdn>North American Datum of 1983</horizdn> <ellips>Geodetic Reference System 80</ellips> <semiaxis>6378137.000000</semiaxis> <denflat>298.257222</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>Potential evapotranspiration</enttypl> <enttypd>Estimated values of potential evapotranspiration, in mm.</enttypd> <enttypds>TWS</enttypds> </enttyp> </detailed> <overview> <eaover>These data represent decadal mean totals of potential evapotranspiration estimates (mm).</eaover> <eadetcit> Please see the associated document Hamon_PET_equations.pdf (http://www.snap.uaf.edu/attachments/Hamon_PET_equations.pdf )  for the equations used. Scripts used for the calculation are available upon request to SNAP. Lu, Jianbiao; Sun, Ge; McNulty, Steven G.; Amatya, Devendra (2005). A comparison of six potential evaportranspiration methods for regional use in the southeastern United States. Journal of the American Water Resources Association, 41, 621- 633. </eadetcit> </overview> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</cntorg>
